name: Active Start (5-6)
description: Foundation stage focusing on fun, play, and basic movement skills. Children should experience a wide variety of physical activities in safe, structured environments. Emphasis on enjoyment over competition. Source: LTAD Model

name: FUNdamentals (6-8)
description: Critical window for developing fundamental movement skills through structured play and varied activities. Focus on the ABCs of athleticism: Agility, Balance, Coordination, and Speed. Multi-sport participation strongly encouraged. Source: NSCA Youth Training Guidelines

name: Learn to Train (8-11)
description: Window of accelerated motor development - optimal time for learning sport-specific skills. Focus on proper technique before intensity. Introduction to basic training concepts. Continue multi-sport participation. Source: AAP Organized Sports Guidelines

name: Train to Train (11-15)
description: Build aerobic base, strength foundation, and sport-specific skills during growth spurt. Critical period for developing training habits. Begin sport specialization consideration (typically after age 12-13 for most sports). Introduction to periodization concepts. Source: NSCA LTAD Position Statement

name: Train to Compete (15-18)
description: Sport-specific training optimization, competition preparation, and college recruitment phase. Advanced strength and conditioning. Position specialization. Mental performance training. Academic-athletic balance critical for NCAA eligibility. Source: NCAA Eligibility Guidelines, USA Sport Development Models
